Message.Title: shares should continue to exceed expectations
Message.Msg: I remember goldman giving a strong buy to x when it was at 180, their price target was 220...... In fact, Pacific Crest had upgraded the retailer's rating to "Outperform" from "Sector Perform" and set a price target of $346 because the company's lead is growing in its sector, and recent gains in market share should sustain growth. Goldman Sachs also set a "buy" rating at a more conservative $315 price target, saying the growth of e-commerce is driven by shrinking traditional retail footprints and favorable consumer demographics, while indicating that Amazon's shares should continue to exceed expectations.
Getting tense. 276.25 still in play.

Message.Title: AMZN is a very slow reacting stock.
Message.Msg: Bad news comes out (e.g. AAPL). People assume AMZN would go down hard. It doesn't. Actually, it does the exact opposite of what people expect: it goes up. After a while, people, even shorts, start thinking AMZN weathered the bad news well, so it is likely to go up more when bad news stops surfacing. Then the stock moves in the direction most natural for it. In today's case, down. Now, the question is how slow the reaction of AMZN will be today.

Technically, if you accept that the old all-time high was 274.50 (a premarket high). AMZN's major breakout has failed already. You could go for 274.26 (regular hour high), you still have a few nickels, but based on my experience, I think AMZN is done for the day.

Message.Title: Keynesian central bankers have made it krystal clear no nation with a printing press
Message.Msg: Will ever need to default:)
Now what? The initial objective is met. Should I buy calls now?

Amazon is a growth stock that is promising to be huge and *one day* make a ton of money. But that's the rub, Amazon is growing by spending everything it take in leaving nothing for profits. The question is: is that a good investment of funds? If it is, then down the road (1, 2, 5, 10yrs?), Amazon should be making tons of profit for its shareholders. On the other hand, if it needs to keep spending like this just to keep growing an undercutting the competition, then this is just Jeff Bezo's hobby, and shareholders are just funding his fun. I'm sitting it out as I think all companies of this size owe their shareholders some decent return, even if it means slowing growth, or raising prices slightly. Its too easy to just keep growing, but never making a dime. What happens to the stock if the growth falters? 50% drop? A true traders stock to play the market.
anyone follow this one . . . +40%

Message.Title: Anyone get a notice in their e-mail?
Message.Msg: Amazon just sent me a e-mail saying I owe the government taxes for the things I bought in 2012. This seems very inconvenient as I buy a lot of stuff from them if I was supposed to pay taxes shouldn't they have charged them to me at the time of purchase? Now they have all accrued and could be a substantial amount of money as we buy a lot of electronics as well as food and dietary supplement items from them. I've been buying from them for over 10 years and this has never happened.. Will they start charging tax on their website or will they keep with this accruing tax system? Could this not be the straw that breaks the camels back? When a stock skyrockets with falling earnings you begin to wonder what it will take..

Message.Title: A reminder From July 12, 2011 on nflx..... Sybil waz short an arsload from here....
Message.Msg: GOLDMAN: Netflix Is A Screaming Buy, Price Target $330 by Pascal-Emmanuel Gobry | Jul. 12, 2011, 6:05 AM | 1,380 Goldman has a note out upping its price target on Netflix to $330. The big reason? Overseas. Netflix recently announced a big expansion to Latin America, and Goldman says Netflix is going to do great there. Why? Latin America has 3.5X the number of broadband households as Canada, Netflix's previous international expansion, and growing fast; US content is really popular there and Netflix can buy it cheaply; There's very little direct competition, mostly pay TV. As fast as Netflix has been growing, it's important to remember that the company has a huge market opportunity ahead of it, as overseas shows. Don't Miss Our Exclusive Interview With Netflix CEO Reed Hastings →

Message.Msg: Bruce... God bless you man. I am happy you're making $$$ in amzn. And I hope you keep every penny you've made! I write this with respect... a lot of what you write is incorrect. amzn went to market with 2.5 billion in debt. Granted, the debt is at low interest rates. Ask yourself why jb, who endlessly touts his free cash flow machine, went to borrow $2.5b. In addition, amzn has huge fixed costs. They have to pay for the warehouses, the data centers, etc. There variable cost is big to (shipping costs) I know you think that fundamentals don't apply to amzn, and, to tell you the truth, they haven't mattered recently. BUT one day they will matter, and when that day comes, AMZN will drop so fast, it will be tough to get out and keep those great gains you've earn. Hey, man, I'm just like you in the sense that I'm a small time retail guy trying to make a few $$$.

The U.S. has been bankrupt since 1933. The U.S. citizens then alive and yet to born were pledged as collateral when the U.S. bent bankrupt that year. That's why most of us have to work and pay income tax. (The Internal Revenue Service is not an agency of the U.S. government. It's a section of the Federal Reserve System, a private organization.)
The Internal Revenue Service (IRS) is part of the United States federal government, a bureau of the Department of the Treasury.
